Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Overcoming crown shyness: lianas determine ant community structure in the tropical rain forest canopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although much of the world's biodiversity exists in the rainforest canopy, little is known about the factors that maintain that diversity or cause it to vary across the landscape. Quantifying such factors is important because the structure of tropical forests is rapidly changing. In particular, the abundance of one major canopy component " lianas (woody vines) " is increasing due to disturbance and climate change. Because lianas physically connect neighboring trees, changes in their abundance should affect the distribution, behavior, and diversity of non-flying animals that live in the canopy. This project tests that hypothesis in Panama by creating a large-scale experiment in which lianas are added or removed from some forest plots and not from others. The project focuses on the response of ants because they are conspicuous, abundant, and play important ecological roles in forests. The research specifically addresses three interrelated questions. First, how does the physical connectivity provided by lianas affect ant diversity in tree crowns? Second, do lianas help restore canopy ant communities in forests that have been cut or otherwise disturbed? Finally, do different ant species prefer to use different types of lianas, and why?

Tropical rainforests are the world's best classroom for studying biodiversity, and this project provides outstanding opportunities for students at the University of Louisville to gain valuable first-hand research experience in an international setting. Likewise, local K-12 teachers will collect data in Panama while developing curricula on rainforest conservation for use during the school year. Because the field site is a popular tourist destination, the project provides a unique opportunity for participants to interact regularly with the general public. Prior research on rainforest canopies has attracted international media attention, and this project is expected to generate similar public interest. Finally, the work will reveal how changes in tropical forest structure may shape canopy biodiversity over the next several decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this research was to determine how lianas (woody vines) affect arboreal ant diversity in the tropical forest canopy of Panama.  Secondarily, this project explored the behavioral and morphological mechanisms by which ants interact with lianas, and the unique selection pressures faced by arthropods living and foraging in tropical tree crowns. 

Intellectual Merit: Although much of the world's biodiversity exists in the rainforest canopy, little is known about the factors that maintain that diversity or cause it to vary across the landscape.  The abundance of one major canopy component?lianas (woody vines)?is increasing due to disturbance and climate change.  This project determined how such changes in liana abundance could affect the structure of canopy ant communities.  The project focused on ants because they are conspicuous, abundant, and play important ecological roles in tropical forests. 

We removed lianas from individual trees and from forest plots, then replaced some of the lost connectivity by stringing old climbing ropes between tree crowns (Figure 1).  We also added various types of artificial ant nests (e.g., wood blocks; Figure 2) to determine how ant colonization of trees differs when lianas are absent or present.  We found that the physical connections between tree crowns provided by lianas affect the species composition and local diversity of ants.  However, the effects of lianas on ant diversity was minimal in very young forests.  Ant colonization of artificial nests was higher (73% occupied) in trees without lianas vs. trees with lianas (28% occupied).  However, artificial nests typically were colonized by existing resident ant species.  Thus, we concluded that nest addition did not affect ant community structure.  Collectively, these results show that tropical trees are ecological islands for flightless animals like ants, and that the physical connections provided by lianas promote the presence of ant species that forage over large areas.  

Secondarily, we explored how the physical characteristics of tree surfaces (branches and trunks) and liana stems affect the nesting, locomotion, and foraging behaviors of different ant species.  Laboratory and field experiments showed that the relatively smooth surfaces of liana stems promote faster running speeds in ants, and that the adhesive forces of common canopy ant species are sensitive to the wetness of plant substrates.  We also found that the high temperatures of canopy surfaces can influence adhesive performance and foraging decisions in ants.  Temperatures on the upper surfaces of tropical tree branches commonly exceed 50C (Figure 3), which is a major obstacle to foraging.  Ongoing studies indicate that ants will evacuate twig nests (which are commonly associated with lianas) at fairly predictable temperatures, and that such "absconding" temperatures differ among ant species. 

Finally, we explored how the presence of lianas affects the abundance of nests of Azteca trigona, a common and ecologically important canopy ant species (Figure 4).  We also examined how ant brain anatomy differs between species that live near the ground vs. those that live in the canopy (Figure 5).  Average Azteca trigona nest abundance increased in forest plots following liana removal, but the mechanism for this effects remains unknown.  Ongoing analyses are revealing that optic regions of canopy ant brains are larger than those of understory species.  

Broader Impacts:  Tropical rainforests are the world's best classroom for studying biodiversity, and this project provided outstanding opportunities for students at the University of Louisville (a metropolitan campus in an EPSCoR state) to gain valuable first-hand research experience in an international setting.  This project contributed to one finished PhD degree, one finished M.S. degree, two completed undergraduate honors theses, one completed REU project, and one undergraduate honors thesis currently in progress.  This project also enhanced the development and training of numerous undergraduate and graduate students (especially women).  Almost all of the undergraduates have already, or will soon enter graduate or professional schools.  This project provided professional development opportunities for two female doctoral students (one Latin American and one Native American) and two female postdoctoral researchers in the Yanoviak lab.  Likewise, three different local K-12 teachers collected data in Panama while developing curricula on rainforest conservation for use during the school year.  We contributed to local "Beer-with-a-scientist" events, gave research presentations to K-12 students visiting the University of Louisville campus, participated in the ACC Innovation and Creativity Festival at the Smithsonian in Washington DC, had research-related discussions with thousands of ecotourists in Panama, and developed a public education project about ants in collaboration with the Louisville Zoo.  Finally, this project supported the development of a Tropical Biology Field Course that was very successful and remains very popular.  Several students who attended this course presented the results of their independent projects at the annual meeting of the Kentucky Academy of Sciences, and one likely will publish her project in a regional journal.  At least four of the students are now planning to pursue careers in academic research.
